js.user
Class JsNode

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      js.Var<JsObject>
          js.core.JsObject
              js.dom.DOM2Core.Node.Prototype
                  js.user.JsNode
All Implemented Interfaces:
ObjectLike
Direct Known Subclasses:
DOM2Core.Attr.Prototype, DOM2Core.CharacterData.Prototype, DOM2Core.Document.Prototype, DOM2Core.DocumentFragment.Prototype, DOM2Core.Element.Prototype, DOM2Core.ProcessingInstruction.Prototype, JsEntity, JsEntityReference, JsNotation
public class JsNode
extends DOM2Core.Node.Prototype

An opaque class representing JavaScript client-side objects of the global JsClient.Node class.

JsWindow.document object itself) implement this class, which provides the fundamental properties and methods for traversing and manipulating the tree. For Internet Explorer, this class also defines some IE-specific properties and methods for working with XML documents, XPath expressions, and XSLT transforms.

The parentNode property and childNodes array allow you to move up and down the document tree. You can enumerate the children of a given node by looping through the elements of childNodes array or by using the firstChild and nextSibling properties, or the lastChild and previousSibling properties to loop backward. The appendChild(JsNode), insertBefore(JsNode, JsNode), removeChild(JsNode), and replaceChild(JsNode, JsNode) methods allow you to modify the document tree by altering the children of a node.

Every object in a document tree implements both the class and a more specialized subclass, such as JsElement or JsText. The nodeType property specifies which subclass a node implements. You can use this property to test the type of a node before using properties or methods of the more specialized subclass.

The nodeName and nodeValue properties specify additional information about a node, but their value depends on nodeType. Note that subclasses typically define specialized properties, such as the JsElement.tagName property of JsElement nodes and the JsCharacterData.data property of JsText nodes, for obtaining this information.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
JavaScript:
Opaque types can be resolved but no class objects for them can be generated into the target codes. Re-compilers must exit with error on the operations of accessing that kind of class objects. The checkcast operation to the class literal of this interface must be ignored and instanceof to it always true.

ELEMENT_NODE

public static final int ELEMENT_NODE
A legal value for the nodeType property of a JsNode object indicating the type of the node. For the compatibility with IE, you must use this numeric literal directly instead of DOM2Core.Node.ELEMENT_NODE.

Since:
1.0

Constant Field Values

attributes

public static final JsArray.Member attributes

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsElement object refers to a read-only array of JsAttr nodes that represent the attributes of that element. Note that this array is live: any changes to the attributes of the element are immediately visible through it.

Technically, the array is of NamedNodeMap interface which is specified by the Level 1 DOM standard and defines a number of methods for querying, setting, and removing elements. JsElement defines better methods for setting and querying element attributes, and there are no other uses of NamedNodeMap that are relevant to client-side JavaScript. Treat the attributes property as a read-only array of JsAttr objects, or use the methods defined by JsElement to query, set, and delete attributes.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

childNodes

public static final JsNodeList.Member<?> childNodes

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object refers to a read-only array containing the child nodes of the current node. This property should never be null and for nodes with no children, the length of the array is zero. The property is actually a JsNodeList object, but it behaves just like a read-only array of JsNode objects. Note that the JsNodeList object is live: any changes to this element's list of children are immediately visible through the JsNodeList object.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

firstChild

public static final JsNode.Member firstChild

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object is a read-only reference to the first child of the node, or null if the node has no children.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

lastChild

public static final JsNode.Member lastChild

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object is a read-only reference to the last child of the node, or null if the node has no children.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

nextSibling

public static final JsNode.Member nextSibling

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object is a read-only reference to the sibling node that immediately follows the current node in the childNodes array of the parentNode of the current one, or null if there is no such node.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

parentNode

public static final JsNode.Member parentNode

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object is a read-only reference to the parent or container node of that node, or null if there is no parent. Note that the JsDocument, JsDocumentFragment, and JsAttr nodes never have parent nodes. Also, nodes that have been removed from the document, or that are newly created and have not yet been inserted into the document tree, have a parentNode of null.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

previousSibling

public static final JsNode.Member previousSibling

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object is a read-only reference to the sibling node that immediately precedes the current node in the childNodes array of the parentNode of the current one, or null if there is no such node.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

ownerDocument

public static final JsDocument.Member ownerDocument

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object is a read-only reference to the JsDocument object of which the node is a part. For JsDocument nodes, the property is null.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

localName

public static final Value.String.Member localName

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object refers to a read-only string specifying the local part of the element or attribute name for XML documents that use name spaces. The property is never used with HTML documents.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
namespaceURI, prefix
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

namespaceURI

public static final Value.String.Member namespaceURI

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsElement or JsAttr object refers to a read-only string specifying URI of the name space of the node for XML documents that use name spaces. The property is never used with HTML documents.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
localName, prefix
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

nodeName

public static final Value.String.Member nodeName

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object refers to a read-only string specifying the name of the node. For JsElement nodes, it specifies the tag name of the element, which can also be retrieved with the JsElement.tagName property. For other types of nodes, the value of nodeName depends on the node type:

  • ELEMENT_NODE: The element's tag name.
  • ATTRIBUTE_NODE: The attribute name.
  • TEXT_NODE: "#text"
  • CDATA_SECTION_NODE: "#cdata-section"
  • PROCESSING_INSTRUCTION_NODE: The target of the PI.
  • COMMENT_NODE: "#comment"
  • DOCUMENT_NODE: "#document"
  • DOCUMENT_TYPE_NODE: The document type name.
  • DOCUMENT_FRAGMENT_NODE: "#document-fragment"

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

nodeType

public static final Value.Number.Member nodeType

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object refers to a read-only integer value represents the type of the node specifying which sub-interface the node implements. The legal values are:

  • DOM2Core.Node.ELEMENT_NODE or ELEMENT_NODE for JsElement nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.ATTRIBUTE_NODE or ATTRIBUTE_NODE for JsAttr nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.TEXT_NODE or TEXT_NODE for JsText nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.CDATA_SECTION_NODE or CDATA_SECTION_NODE for JsCDATASection nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.PROCESSING_INSTRUCTION_NODE or PROCESSING_INSTRUCTION_NODE for JsProcessingInstruction nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.COMMENT_NODE or COMMENT_NODE for JsComment nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.DOCUMENT_NODE or DOCUMENT_NODE for JsDocument nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.DOCUMENT_TYPE_NODE or DOCUMENT_TYPE_NODE for JsDocumentType nodes
  • DOM2Core.Node.DOCUMENT_FRAGMENT_NODE or DOCUMENT_FRAGMENT_NODE for JsDocumentFragment nodes
For the compatibility with IE, you must use the static numeric literals JsClient.Node.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

nodeValue

public static final Value.String.Member nodeValue

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsNode object refers to a read-only string specifying the value of the node. For JsText nodes, it holds the text content. For other types of nodes, the value depends on the value of nodeType:

  • ELEMENT_NODE: null
  • ATTRIBUTE_NODE: The attribute value.
  • TEXT_NODE: The text of the node.
  • CDATA_SECTION_NODE: The text of the node.
  • PROCESSING_INSTRUCTION_NODE: The remainder of the PI.
  • COMMENT_NODE: The text of the comment.
  • DOCUMENT_NODE: null
  • DOCUMENT_TYPE_NODE: null
  • DOCUMENT_FRAGMENT_NODE: null

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

prefix

public static final Value.String.Member prefix

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsElement or JsAttr object refers to a read-only string specifying the name space prefix of the node for XML documents that use name spaces. The property is never used with HTML documents.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

xml

public static final Value.String.Member xml

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsElement or JsAttr object refers to a read-only string specifying the text of the XML document or an element within an XML document.

Note that the property is IE-Specific. Compare this property to the JsHTMLElement.innerHTML property, and see JsXMLSerializer for a cross-platform alternative.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsHTMLElement.innerHTML, JsXMLSerializer
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

appendChild

public JsNode appendChild(JsNode newChild)

Adds a node to the document tree by appending it to the childNodes array of this node.

This method adds the node newChild to the document, inserting it as the last child of this node. If newChild is already in the document tree, it is removed from the tree and then reinserted at its new location. If newChild is a JsDocumentFragment node, it is not inserted itself; instead, all its children are appended, in order, to the end of this node's childNodes array. Note that a node from (or created by) one document cannot be inserted into a different document. That is, the ownerDocument property of newChild must be the same as the ownerDocument property of this node.

Parameters:
newChild - The node to be inserted into the document. If the node is of JsDocumentFragment, it is not directly inserted, but each of its children are.
Returns:
The node that was added.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR if the node does not allow children, it does not allow children of the specified type, or newChild is an ancestor of this node (or is this node itself), the value JsDOMException.WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR if the ownerDocument property of newChild is not the same as the ownerDocument property of this node, or the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow children to be appended, or the node being appended is already part of the document tree, and its parent is read-only and does not allow children to be removed. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

cloneNode

public JsNode cloneNode(java.lang.Boolean deep)

Makes a copy of this node, or of the node and all its descendants.

This method makes and returns a copy of the node on which it is called. If passed the argument true, it recursively clones all descendants of the node as well. Otherwise, it clones only the node and none of its children. The returned node is not part of the document tree, and its parentNode property is null. When a JsElement node is cloned, all of its attributes are also cloned. Note, however, that event listener functions registered on a node are not cloned.

Parameters:
deep - true to clone recursively all descendants of the node; Otherwise, clone only this node.
Returns:
A copy of this node.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
cloneNode(JsBoolean), cloneNode(Value)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

cloneNode

public JsNode cloneNode(Value<java.lang.Boolean> deep)

Makes a copy of this node, or of the node and all its descendants.

This method makes and returns a copy of the node on which it is called. If passed the argument true, it recursively clones all descendants of the node as well. Otherwise, it clones only the node and none of its children. The returned node is not part of the document tree, and its parentNode property is null. When a JsElement node is cloned, all of its attributes are also cloned. Note, however, that event listener functions registered on a node are not cloned.

insertAdjacentElement

public java.lang.Object insertAdjacentElement(java.lang.String where,
                                              JsNode node)

Inserts an element at the specified location.

This method is IE-specific.

Parameters:
where - A string that specifies where to insert the HTML element, using one of the following values:
  • "beforeBegin": Inserts node immediately before the object.
  • "afterBegin": Inserts node after the start of the object but before all other content in the object.
  • "beforeEnd": Inserts node immediately before the end of the object but after all other content in the object.
  • "afterEnd": Inserts node immediately after the end of the object.
node - An object that specifies the element to be inserted adjacent to the object that invoked the method.
Returns:
An element object.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

insertAdjacentHTML

public void insertAdjacentHTML(java.lang.String where,
                               java.lang.String html)

Inserts the given HTML text into the element at the location.

This method is IE-specific.

Parameters:
where - A string that specifies where to insert the HTML text, using one of the following values:
  • "beforeBegin": Inserts html immediately before the object.
  • "afterBegin": Inserts html after the start of the object but before all other content in the object.
  • "beforeEnd": Inserts html immediately before the end of the object but after all other content in the object.
  • "afterEnd": Inserts html immediately after the end of the object.
html - A string that specifies the HTML text to insert. The string can be a combination of text and HTML tags. This must be well-formed, valid HTML or this method will fail.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

insertAdjacentText

public void insertAdjacentText(java.lang.String where,
                               java.lang.String text)

Inserts the given text into the element at the location.

This method is IE-specific.

Parameters:
where - A string that specifies where to insert the text, using one of the following values:
  • "beforeBegin": Inserts text immediately before the object.
  • "afterBegin": Inserts text after the start of the object but before all other content in the object.
  • "beforeEnd": Inserts text immediately before the end of the object but after all other content in the object.
  • "afterEnd": Inserts text immediately after the end of the object.
text - A string that specifies the text to insert. The text inserted into the element is plain text.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

insertBefore

public JsNode insertBefore(JsNode newChild,
                           JsNode refChild)

Inserts a node into the document tree immediately before the specified child of this node.

This method inserts the node newChild into the document tree as a child of this node. The new node is positioned within this node's childNodes array so that it comes immediately before the refChild node. If refChild is null, newChild is inserted at the end of childNodes, just as with the appendChild(JsNode) method. Note that it is illegal to call this method with a refChild that is not a child of this node.

If the node being inserted is already in the tree, it is removed and reinserted at its new location.

If newChild is a JsDocumentFragment node, it is not inserted itself; instead, each of its children is inserted, in order, at the specified location.

Parameters:
newChild - The node to be inserted into the document. If the node is of JsDocumentFragment, it is not directly inserted, but each of its children are.
refChild - The child of this node before which newChild is to be inserted. If this argument is null, newChild is inserted as the last child of this node.
Returns:
The node that was inserted.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR if the node does not allow children, it does not allow children of the specified type, or newChild is an ancestor of this node (or is this node itself), the value JsDOMException.WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR if the ownerDocument property of newChild is not the same as the ownerDocument property of this node, the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow insertion, or the parent of newChild is read-only and does not allow deletion, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_FOUND_ERR if refChild is not a child of this node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

isSupported

public final java.lang.Boolean isSupported(java.lang.Object feature,
                                           java.lang.Object version)

Determines if the specified version number of a named feature is supported by this node.

The W3C DOM standard is modular, and implementations are not required to implement all modules or features of the standard. This method tests whether the implementation of this node supports the specified version of the named feature.

Parameters:
feature - The name of the feature to test. The complete set of valid module names for the DOM Level 2 standard that may be used as this argument are listed as follows:
  • Core: Node, Element, Document, Text, and the other fundamental interfaces required by all DOM implementations are implemented. All conforming implementations must support this module.
  • HTML: HTMLElement, HTMLDocument, and the other HTML-specific interfaces are implemented.
  • XML: Entity, EntityReference, ProcessingInstruction, Notation, and the other node types that are useful only with XML documents are implemented.
  • StyleSheets: Simple interfaces describing generic style-sheets are implemented.
  • CSS: Interfaces that are specific to CSS style-sheets are implemented.
  • CSS2: The CSS2Properties interface is implemented.
  • Events: The basic event-handling interfaces are implemented.
  • UIEvents: The interfaces for user-interface events are implemented.
  • MouseEvents: The interfaces for mouse events are implemented.
  • HTMLEvents: The interfaces for HTML events are implemented.
  • MutationEvents: The interfaces for document mutation events are implemented.
  • Range: The interfaces for manipulating ranges of a document are implemented.
  • Traversal: The interfaces for advanced document traversal are implemented.
  • Views: The interfaces for document views are implemented.
version - The version number of the feature to test, or the empty string to test for support of any version of the feature. In the Level 2 DOM specification, supported version numbers are 1.0 and 2.0.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsDOMImplementation.hasFeature(String, String)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

normalize

public final void normalize()

Normalizes all JsText node descendants of this node by deleting empty JsText nodes and merging adjacent JsText nodes.

This method traverses all descendants of this node and normalizes the document by removing any empty JsText nodes and merging all adjacent JsText nodes into a single node. This can simplify the tree structure after node insertions or deletions.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsText
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

removeChild

public JsNode removeChild(JsNode oldChild)

Removes and returns the specified child node from the document tree.

This method removes the specified child from the childNodes array of this node. It is an error to call this method with a node that is not a child. This method returns the oldChild node after removing it. oldChild continues to be a valid node and may be reinserted into the document later.

Parameters:
oldChild - The child node to remove.
Returns:
The node that was removed.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow children to be removed, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_FOUND_ERR if oldChild is not a child of this node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

replaceChild

public JsNode replaceChild(JsNode newChild,
                           JsNode oldChild)

Removes and returns the specified child node from the document tree, replacing it with another node.

This method replaces one node of the document tree with another. oldChild is the node to be replaced and must be a child of this node. newChild is the node that takes its place in the childNodes array of this node.

If newChild is already part of the document, it is first removed from the document before being reinserted at its new position.

If newChild is a JsDocumentFragment node, it is not inserted itself; instead, each of its children is inserted, in order, at the position formerly occupied by oldChild.

Parameters:
newChild - The replacement node.
oldChild - The node to be replaced.
Returns:
The node that was removed from the document and replaced.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR if the node does not allow children, it does not allow children of the specified type, or newChild is an ancestor of this node (or is this node itself), the value JsDOMException.WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR if newChild and this node have different values for ownerDocument property, the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only and does not allow replacement, or newChild is the child of a node that does not allow removals, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_FOUND_ERR if oldChild is not a child of this node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

transformNode

public final java.lang.String transformNode(JsDocument xslt)

Applies an XSLT stylesheet to this node and returns the results as a string.

This IE-specific method transforms a node and its descendants according to the rules specified in an XSLT stylesheet and returns the result as an unparsed string. The method exists only on the nodes of XML documents, not HTML documents. Note that since JsDocument objects are themselves nodes, this method can be applied to entire XML documents.

See JsXSLTProcessor for a cross-platform alternative.

Parameters:
xslt - An XSLT stylesheet, parsed to a JsDocument object.
Returns:
The text produced by applying the specified stylesheet to this node and its descendants.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

transformNodeToObject

public final JsDocument transformNodeToObject(JsDocument xslt)

applies an XSLT stylesheet to this node and returns the results as a new JsDocument object.

This IE-specific method transforms a node and its descendants according to the rules specified in an XSLT stylesheet and returns the result as a JsDocument object. The method exists only on the nodes of XML documents, not HTML documents. Note that since JsDocument objects are themselves nodes, this method can be applied to entire XML documents.

See JsXSLTProcessor for a cross-platform alternative.

Parameters:
xslt - An XSLT stylesheet, parsed to a JsDocument object.
Returns:
The current object itself.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.
